title: 105_s2433
content: TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION: Amends the Consumer Credit Protection Act to include provisions for protecting financial information privacy. The Financial Information Privacy Act includes provisions such as definitions, privacy protection for customer information, enforcement measures, civil liability, criminal penalties, and guidance on agency regulations. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines customer information as data maintained by a financial institution related to its customers, and a document as any form of information. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines customer information as data held by a financial institution regarding its customers, and a document as any form of information. A financial institution is broadly defined as any entity providing financial services to customers with accounts or relationships. This includes depository institutions, loan companies, finance companies, and credit card issuers. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines customer information as data held by a financial institution regarding its customers. The Act broadly defines a financial institution as any entity providing financial services to customers, including depository institutions, loan companies, finance companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may further define the term 'financial institution' for the purposes of the Act. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through false pretenses, such as making fraudulent statements to deceive employees. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through false pretenses, such as making fraudulent statements to deceive employees into releasing the information. This can include making false statements, providing forged documents, or using deceitful tactics to gain access to customer data. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through false pretenses, such as using forged documents or making fraudulent statements to deceive employees. It is also a violation to solicit someone to obtain customer information under false pretenses. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through false pretenses. Law enforcement agencies are exempt from this provision, and financial institutions are also exempt in certain cases. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits financial institutions from obtaining customer information for security testing, misconduct investigations, or information recovery. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits financial institutions from obtaining customer information for certain purposes. Enforcement of this act is carried out by the Federal Trade Commission. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits financial institutions from obtaining customer information for certain purposes. The Federal Trade Commission enforces compliance with this act, similar to its enforcement powers under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. Compliance with the act can also be enforced by other agencies such as the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency for national banks and member banks of the Federal Reserve. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits financial institutions from obtaining customer information for certain purposes. Enforcement is done by the Federal Trade Commission and other agencies like the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency for national banks and member banks of the Federal Reserve. This includes banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits financial institutions from obtaining customer information for certain purposes, enforced by agencies like the Federal Trade Commission, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for insured banks. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits financial institutions from obtaining customer information for certain purposes, enforced by agencies like the Federal Trade Commission, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for insured banks. Violations of this title are treated as violations of other laws by relevant agencies, such as the National Credit Union Administration for Federal credit unions. The Financial Information Privacy Act allows agencies to enforce compliance with the law. States can also take action to stop violations by bringing legal actions. States can enforce compliance with the Financial Information Privacy Act by bringing legal actions in court to enjoin violations, recover damages up to $1,000 per violation on behalf of residents, and be awarded costs and attorney fees for successful actions. Federal regulators also have rights to enforce the law. The State must provide prior written notice to the Federal Trade Commission and relevant agencies before taking any action under the Financial Information Privacy Act. This notice should include a copy of the complaint, unless prior notice is not feasible. The State must serve immediate notice upon instituting action if prior notice is not feasible. The Federal Trade Commission or relevant agencies have the right to intervene, be heard on all matters, and remove the action to the appropriate court. The chief law enforcement officer or designated state official has investigatory powers to conduct investigations and compel witnesses or evidence for actions under this subsection. "Limitation on state action during federal civil action for violation of this title. No State can bring action against defendant named in Federal Trade Commission complaint for alleged violation of this title while federal action is pending. Civil liability for non-compliance with provisions of this title." Failure to comply with provisions of this title regarding financial institutions or customer information may result in liability to the institution or customer for actual damages sustained or amounts received by the non-compliant party. Failure to comply with provisions of this title may result in liability for actual damages or nonmonetary consideration. Additional damages and attorneys' fees may also be awarded. Violators of section 1003 may face fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. Section 1003 violations may result in fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. Aggravated cases involving over $100,000 in illegal activity may face enhanced penalties of up to 10 years in prison. This title does not supersede state laws. ``Sec. 1008. Agency guidance in furtherance of the objectives of this title, each Federal banking agency must adhere to state laws unless they conflict with this title, in which case the greater protection prevails.`` The banking agency issues advisories to depository institutions to prevent illegal activities. The Comptroller General will report to Congress on the effectiveness of remedies within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will report to Congress on the effectiveness of remedies provided in amendments to address fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information and recommend additional legislative or regulatory actions to protect financial privacy.
